newsitem.title: CANADA: ELAN CEO says firm to stay the course.
newsitem.headline: ELAN CEO says firm to stay the course.

text.p: ELAN Energy Inc Chief Executive Verne Johnson, whose company's stock was savaged by investors on Friday following a negative analyst's report on its prospects, said the firm planned to stick to its current strategy developing its vast reserves of heavy oil.

"We think there's considerable value in our strategy and in our assets and we have the program in hand to create that value going forward and that hasn't changed," Johnson said in aa telephone interview.

The report, released late on Thursday by First Energy Capital Corp analyst Martin Molyneaux, recommended investors sell the stock based on a deepening price discount for Canadian heavy oil, flagging production volumes, high operating costs and second-quarter cash flow well below last year's figure.
He revised his 12-month target price to 6.60.
The assessment sent ELAN stock into a tailspin, dropping 1.25 to a new year low of 8.00 on turnover of over 3.3 million shares on Friday.

Johnson, who would not comment directly on the report's specifics, said the data expected to result in the poor second-quarter showing was made public last month at the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers investment symposium.

"I said at CAPP the second quarter was going to be a flat quarter on production and because price was down, the second quarter versus the first quarter, cash flow would be lower than expected," he said. "Today, it got figured out, I guess."
Despite the lower-than-expected production levels, Johnson said ELAN had no plans to make an acquisition to beef up 1997 numbers.

"We have, first of all, such a significant amount of potential in drilling to add production that we don't feel we have to do anything like that," But...we are always on the lookout for opportunities," he said.

He acknowledged last month that, with the poor second-quarter performance, ELAN was vulnerable as a takeover target, a key reason for the implementation of a poison pill at the time. ((Reuters Calgary Bureau (403) 531-1624))
